thread.title: Amazon.com Soars To Record High On Strong Q3 AMZN ECOM MSFT NFLX - Investors.com
thread.title_full: Amazon.com Soars To Record High On Strong Q3 AMZN ECOM MSFT NFLX - Investors.com

author: yahoo
title: Amazon.com Soars To Record High On Strong Q3 AMZN ECOM MSFT NFLX - Investors.com
text:
A mazon.com (NASDAQ: AMZN ) stock hurtled to an all-time high Friday after the e-commerce juggernaut's Q3 earnings came in well above analyst expectations. 
The strong growth from North American and international retail business , plus its cloud division, Amazon Web Services, contributed to higher-than-expected operating profit margins — the highest in five years, RBC Capital Markets analyst Mark Mahaney said in a research note. 
On a constant-currency basis, said Mahaney, Amazon's sales rose 30% year over year, which he said was the biggest jump in three years.   View Enlarged Image 

Amazon's North American gross merchandise volume captured 36% of all total retail growth this year, estimates Wells Fargo analyst Matt Nemer. 
"Amazon's continued wallet share gain, likely as a result of increasing Prime membership count" helped spark the strong quarter, Benchmark analyst Daniel Kurnos said in a research report. 
Amazon swung to a per-share profit of 17 cents from a per-share loss in the year-earlier quarter . Analysts had expected a 13-cent loss. Mahaney said that Amazon's operating income had risen 66%, higher than analysts expected. 
At least nine investment banks raised their price targets for Amazon.com stock. JPMorgan Chase was the most bullish, with analyst Doug Anmuth setting an 800 target. 
Amazon stock rose as high as 9.8% Friday before closing at 599.03, up 6.2%. Amazon stock is up 93% this year and carries an IBD Relative Strength Rating of 98, where 99 is the highest. 
Global growth for Amazon.com's e-commerce business was strong for the second quarter in a row, Canaccord Genuity analyst Michael Graham wrote in a research note. "What was especially positive was that each segment and region contributed to the acceleration," he said in a research note. 
The company's electronics and general merchandise e-commerce sales, which make up about 70% of the company's total revenue, jumped 27% from Q3 2014, Graham pointed out. 
Prime Key To Growth 
Amazon's Prime membership remains one of the company's key tools. About 40% of Amazon.com customers, or 60 to 80 million customers, might be Prime members, according to an RBC Capital Markets survey last month. The survey found that 75% of Prime members said that they bought more from Amazon after joining Prime. About half the Prime members said that they spend $800 or more a year at Amazon, vs. 16% for non-Prime customers. 
Innovations like Prime Day — a Black Friday-like "holiday" that the company held for the first time on July 15 and that offered deals and discount Prime membership — also boosted revenue. In fact, analysts estimated that Prime Day alone accounted for 2 percentage points of Amazon's Q3 revenue growth.
